title: A framework for an open and scalable infrastructure for health data exemplified by the DD2 initiative (NNF21OC0069462)
details: Grant from the NNF Data Science Research Infrastructure Programme to develop an infrastructure for managing, sharing, and discovering data. NNF posted a brief [description](https://datascience.novonordiskfonden.dk/projects/a-framework-for-an-open-and-scalable-infrastructure-for-health-data-exemplified-by-the-dd2-initiative/) of it.

details: Responsible for managing the finances, identifying potential sources of funding and applying to them as applicable, reimbursing students for expenses, and buying the snacks for the coding sessions. title: Gordon Cressy Student Leadership Award
details: For recognition of outstanding extra-curricular contributions to the faculty and the university as a whole. Contributions include creating a workshop series (offered in the Graduate Professional Skills program) to teach coding to graduate students, playing an instrumental role in starting a student group (UofTCoders) to allow for peer-level skill sharing of coding and programming for science and research, and for running short, twice-monthly coding sessions in the Department of Nutritional Sciences.

title: Code as Manuscript: Data wrangling, visualization, and reproducibility in R
details: Developed a multi-day workshop series on initially SAS with colleague Dr. Daiva Nielsen and later I developed a series on R. These workshops aimed to teach scientific coding skills to graduate students, such as using version control, structuring research projects, using reproducibility concepts, and "software development" concepts in a scientific coding context. The material is publicly available online at https://github.com/codeasmanuscript.
organization: Graduate Professional Skills Program, University of Toronto

title: Validating a bioelectric impedance instrument against the gold standard dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry on measures of adiposity.
details: For the Research Projects course (NFS394) in Nutritional Sciences. Co-mentored with Dr. Anthony Hanley. Supervision consisted of helping guide the development of the research question and teaching Windy coding in SAS and using statistical techniques to analyze the data.
organization: Department of Nutritional Sciences, University of Toronto

title: Metabolomic Profiling of the DASH Diet: Novel Insights for the Nutritional Epidemiology of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
details: Master's Student in Nutritional Sciences. Co-mentored with Dr. Anthony Hanley. Trained Shahen in R and statistics, assisted in guiding the research project and analysis.
organization: Department of Nutritional Sciences, University of Toronto

title: Pipeline in R for creating multi-metabolite signatures of dietary adherence from observational data
details: Master’s student doing a PhD at Gothenburg, Sweden while completing a (remote) Master’s certificate in Biostatistics and Bioinformatics.

title: Scientific program organizing committee for the Danish Diabetes Academy Postdoctoral Winter School

details: Developed the website with the videos of the talks and poster abstracts.
